Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back with only modelling for mouth and clypeus; at side, legs probably well- modelled (not seen); base has deeply incised motif of papyrus flower with drooping buds either side and all three stems rising from straight line as base; glaze all gone or never applied? (said to be unbaked and unglazed on the EEF distribution list); core fine, buff to white in colour; bit chipped.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs with a motif of papyrus thicket depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions on scarabs and scaraboids (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 4-7). This scarab was attributed to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 98-99, type XXVIII, subtype A159-166, see especially A159 for this piece). However, the rather large size of the scarab and the delicate incised outline of the motif are unlike Gorton's type XXVIII. Its size and technique recall more her type XXXIV A (Gorton 1996, 121-123). For related motifs on Naukratis scarabs and scaraboids: BM 1886,0401.1604; BM 1888,0601.1605; Birmingham City Museum and Art Gallery 1888A195.4; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.8. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund). Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 7)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 99, Type XXVIII A159)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.084) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather fair, but chipped and abraded
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4888 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
